Issues.Title: unable to create a redirect for named outlet
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package `@angular/router` ### Is this a regression? Unsure. ### Description I have a named router outlet which I want to default by redirecting the empty path to one of the named paths, e.g. ``` { outlet: 'test', path: '', pathMatch: 'full', redirectTo: 'default' }, { outlet: 'test', path: 'default', component: TestComponent }, ``` This worked when the configuration was in a lazy loaded module, however moving it to the root router configuration now fails to validate. This configuration seems like it should be valid. The only workaround I could find was to use an absolute path, e.g. ``` { path: 'test', pathMatch: 'full', redirectTo: '/test/(test:default)' }, ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-issue-repro2-fikqg2 ## üî• Exception or Error 

Error: Invalid configuration of route 'test/': a componentless route without children or loadChildren cannot have a named outlet set

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): reset style property value defined using [style.prop.px]
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change, setting style prop value to undefined or empty string would not result in resetting prop value in case the style prop is defined using [style.prop.px] syntax. The problem is that the check for empty value (and thus reseting the value) considered successful only in case of `null` value. This commit updates the check to use `isStylingValueDefined` function that also checks for undefined and empty string.

This PR resolves FW-1676.

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): Refactor getTsTypeFromBuiltinType
Issues.Body:
This commit fixes a few issues with helper method
`getBuiltInTypeFromTsType`.

1. The function is wrongly named. It should be the other way round.
2. The ts.Type returned by the function should not contain any value.
This is because for some data types like Number and String, the
SourceFile (context.node) is not the correct value. Value is never
needed for program correctness in this case.
3. For StringLiteral type, the behavior of (2) means that the type is 
not of String, but rather the string literal itself, which is the entire 
SourceFile.

Issues.Title: feat(language-service): completions support for indexed types
Issues.Body:
Previously, indexing a container type would not return completions for
the indexed type because for every TypeScript type, the recorded index
type was always marked as `undefined`, regardless of the index
signature.

This PR now returns the index type of TypeScript containers with numeric
or string index signatures. This allows use to generate completions for
arrays and defined index types:

```typescript
interface Container<T> {
  [key: string]: T;
}
const ctr: Container<T>;
ctr['stringKey']. // gives `T.` completions

const arr: T[];
arr[0]. // gives `T.` completions
```

Note that this does _not_ provide completions for properties indexed by
string literals, e.g.

```typescript
interface Container<T> {
  foo: T;
}
const ctr: Container<T>;
ctr['foo']. // does not give `T.` completions
```

Tests to `compiler-cli/src/diagnostics` have not been added, as that module appears to exclusively serve the Language Service, so in some sense Language Service tests "are enough".

Closes angular/vscode-ng-language-service#110
Closes angular/vscode-ng-language-service#277
Closes #29811 via replacement

Issues.Title: ngtsc/ngc doesn't support --diagnostics command line flags
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/compiler ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... no ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... `tsc` supports a handy flag called `--diagnostics` (also available as `{"compilerOptions": { "diagnostics": true, ‚Ä¶ }}`). This flag causes the compiler to perf stats that look like this: ``` Files: 197 Lines: 58877 Nodes: 209295 Identifiers: 77861 Symbols: 58176 Types: 21014 Memory used: 117488K I/O read: 0.04s I/O write: 0.00s Parse time: 0.87s Bind time: 0.28s Check time: 1.42s Emit time: 0.04s Total time: 2.60s ``` `ngc` doesn't honor this flag, it would be super handy if we preserved this feature in order to be able to understand where the time is spent in the compiler. At minimum we should preserve the output from `tsc`, but even better would be if we added info about Angular specific passes that run on top of tsc. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ` #compare the stdout of: yarn tsc -p tsconfig.app.json --diagnostics # with: yarn ngc -p tsconfig.app.json --diagnostics ` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



9.0.0-rc.1
**Anything else relevant?**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ngtsc/ngc doesn't support --diagnostics command line flags" (#33774)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): avoid infinite recursion when evaluation source files
Issues.Body:
When ngtsc comes across a source file during partial evaluation, it
would determine all exported symbols from that module and evaluate their
values greedily. This greedy evaluation strategy introduces unnecessary
work and can fall into infinite recursion when the evaluation result of
an exported expression would circularly depend on the source file. This
would primarily occur in CommonJS code, where the `exports` variable can
be used to refer to an exported variable. This variable would be
resolved to the source file itself, thereby greedily evaluating all
exported symbols and thus ending up evaluating the `exports` variable
again. This variable would be resolved to the source file itself,
thereby greedily evaluating all exported symbols and thus ending u
evaluating the `exports` variable again. This variable would be
resolved to the source file itself, thereby greedily evaluating all
exported symbols and thus ending up evaluating the `exports` variable
again. This variable would be resolved to the source file itself,
thereby greedily evaluating all exported symbols and thus ending up
evaluating the `exports` variable again. This went on for some time
until all stack frames were exhausted.

This commit introduces a `ResolvedModule` that delays the evaluation of
its exports until they are actually requested. This avoids the circular
dependency when evaluating `exports`, thereby fixing the issue.

Fix #33734
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): avoid infinite recursion when evaluation source files" (#33772)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): align TestBed.overrideProvider with what happens with provi‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶ders in TestBed providers array

In Ivy, if you do:
`TestBed.configureTestingModule({providers: [{provide: Service}]});`
the injector will attempt to inject Service as if it was simply listed
in the providers array like `{providers: [Service]}`
This fixes an inconsistency when similarly providing an override with no
`useValue` or `useFactory`.

Issues.Title: FormArray push issue when formArrayValues are disabled
Issues.Body:
Hi Angular community,

I'm having an issue when I try to push a new formControl into a formArray of formControls.
The issue happens when the other values are disabled.

When other values are disabled, the push will update correctly the ```controls```, **but the values will all be erased and only the new value will be there.**

I found the issue source:
formArray.push calls updateValueAndValidity
updateValueAndValidity calls _updateValue
_updateValue calls ._reduceValue

here's the code source
```https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/8bce694c2f658afc283e26f8adad7f8776e36728/packages/forms/src/model.ts#L1566```

Can somebody explain to me why do the disabled values should be removed from the formArray, or could this be fixed?

Workaround:

I enable everything before, then disable everything after the push:
``` 
///formValue is my FormArray
this.formValues.enable();
this.formValues.push(emptyItem)
this.formValues.disable();
```

Thanks for your attention!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "FormArray push issue when formArrayValues are disabled" (#33768)

Issues.Title: angular.io website is missing titles (SSR, SEO)
Issues.Body:
Hello!

Thank you for your hard work.

However, `https://angular.io/` website is missing the correct titles.

Consider this page:
https://angular.io/guide/lazy-loading-ngmodules

It has a heading: "Lazy Loading Feature Modules", but it's not reflected in the `<title>` when HTML is returned from the server. The title looks like this for all pages: `<title>Angular</title>`, so it makes search results less readable in engines, which doesn't support JavaScript (e.g. DuckDuckGo):

![screenshot-duckduckgo com-2019 11 12-18_47_00](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1702725/68686562-de301c80-057c-11ea-844d-6c429a444a78.png)

I believe this should be fixed on SSR side.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "angular.io website is missing titles (SSR, SEO)" (#33760)

Issues.Title: compareWith should be able to access global variables
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
@angular/forms


### Description
I wrote components that get a string as input which is used to compare objects, as i might want to compare the whole object or just the ID of the objects, depending on it's use.
Sadly the function passed to [compareWith] has no access to the global variables of the component.

### Describe the solution you'd like
The function passed to [compareWith] gets access to the global variables of the component.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Extend the parameters for compareWith to include an optional third parameter used for comparing.
e.g.:

[compareWith]="compare" compareWithIndex="id"

compare(c1: any, c2: any, index: string)

### Example:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-bh1kuo
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "compareWith should be able to access global variables" (#33758)

Issues.Title: Proposal: More intelligent transpilation for Differential Loading
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description


This proposal is inspired by the Chrome team's work on [babel/preset-modules](https://github.com/babel/preset-modules).

Currently, Angular CLI's mechanism for differential loading is simple; creating original bundles targetted in **ES2015** and down-leveling it for ES5 compatible.

But today, _modules-compatible_ browsers can accept more modern JavaScript than `es2015` like `async/await`, Object Spread, Tagged Template, and more. So the Chrome team created a babel preset for getting more compact modern JavaScript.

Please see more https://github.com/babel/preset-modules#how-does-it-work. 

I guess that idea can help also Angular CLI's build process. Generate original bundles for browsers that support ES Modules, and down-leveling it for legacy browsers.

I'm not sure how we can achieve it with TypeScript-based toolchain, but I hope it isn't impossible.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Proposal: More intelligent transpilation for Differential Loading" (#16170)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): ignore node modules when polling
Issues.Body:
The node modules directory contains a massive set of directories and files.  When watching via polling, that set needs to be queried repeatedly to determine if any files have changed.  Changes within node modules are quite rare while using `ng serve` or `ng build --watch`.  As a result, polling the node modules directory is rarely useful.  This change causes CPU usage to drop from a potential high of ~80% to a more manageable ~5-10%.

This also fixes the flag option variant of `--poll` for `ng serve` so that it results in the default value of 500 ms instead of disabling polling.  `ng build --watch` already contains a fix for this.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): ignore node modules when polling" (#16153)

Issues.Title: node-sass build error 404 not found
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package This error appears in the package @angular-devkit/build-angular ### Is this a regression? Yes, this process worked until last week but stopped working with the release of version 0.803.18, although attempting to enforce version 0.803.17 also results in the same error occurring. ### Description The node-sass URL that the process is attempting to use is not valid and does not match a release url for the node-sass project. The one attempting to be used by @angular-devkit/build-angular is at https://github.com/sass/node-sass/releases/download/v4.10.0/win32-x64-72_binding.node, but 72 does not exist in v4.10.0. It likely needs to be updated to https://github.com/sass/node-sass/releases/download/v4.9.0/win32-x64-72_binding.node instead. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create an angular project with a reference to @angular-devkit/build-anguler version 0.803.18 and clear the cached files located in the C:\Users\{UserName}\AppData\Roaming\npm-cache\node-sass\4.10.0\ folder. Attempt to run npm install command on project. (I do not receive this error on my local computer because these files exist, but the error occurs on an Azure DevOps build process fails due to these files not being available ## üî• Exception or Error 

  > node-sass@4.10.0 install D:\a\1\s\CSI.Web\ClientApp\node_modules\@angular-devkit\build-angular\node_modules\node-sass
  > node scripts/install.js
  
  Downloading binary from https://github.com/sass/node-sass/releases/download/v4.10.0/win32-x64-72_binding.node
  Cannot download "https://github.com/sass/node-sass/releases/download/v4.10.0/win32-x64-72_binding.node": 
  
  HTTP error 404 Not Found
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

 /_/   \_\_| |_|\__, |\__,_|_|\__,_|_|       \____|_____|___|
                |___/

Any advice or help to get this resolved quickly would be appreciated, as this is holding up a release that was supposed to go out this week.

Issues.Title: angular 8 application not working in local ISS while using "ng build --prod"
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? **Yes, working fine angular 7** ### Description while hosting my application into local IIS with target "es2015", my application not working. we facing alignment issue due to control rendering initialized before styles loaded in application. But working fine, when i set **target** as "**es5**" ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. download sample from below link: > https://www.syncfusion.com/downloads/support/directtrac/general/ze/RTE1827193720 2. Give "npm i" to install required packages. 3. use below command to build application > ng build --prod ## üî• Exception or Error when target is "**es2015**", application breaks. refer below screenshot ![Screenshot (23)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36756050/68659659-a9609d00-055d-11ea-9ecf-975c7b28c821.png) IF i set **target** as "es5", application works fine. refer below ![Screenshot (22)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36756050/68659979-53402980-055e-11ea-90a8-c2001a8529b9.png) ## üåç Your Environment 



    "@angular/animations": "~8.2.11",
    "@angular/common": "~8.2.11",
    "@angular/compiler": "~8.2.11",
    "@angular/core": "~8.2.11",
    "@angular/forms": "~8.2.11",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "~8.2.11",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "~8.2.11",
--------------------------------------------------------------
    "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "~0.803.10",
    "@angular/cli": "~8.3.10",
    "@angular/compiler-cli": "~8.2.11",
**Anything else relevant?** ensure "es2015" compilation

Issues.Title: App shell gives an SCSS import error when using 'stylePreprocessorOptions' in angular.json
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [x] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? This problem also occurs on angular 7 ### Description I get a scss import error when I try to run "my-app:app-shell", it seems like it doesn't use the "stylePreprocessorOptions->includePaths" option from "angular.json->...->build->options", this problem doesn't occur when running "ng build --prod" or "ng serve" ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create a new project called my-app, make sure to use scss ``` ng new my-app --routing cd my-app ``` Generate the app-shell required files & component ``` ng generate app-shell --client-project my-app --universal-project server-app ``` Create "src/sass/test.scss" file to be imported ``` * { font-size: 64px; } ``` Add "src/sass" to "angular.json" ``` "projects": { "my-app": { "architect": { "build": { "options": { "stylePreprocessorOptions": { "includePaths": [ "src/sass" ] }, } }, "test": { "options": { "stylePreprocessorOptions": { "includePaths": [ "src/sass" ] }, } } } } } ``` Import the test.scss file into "app.component.scss" ``` @import 'test'; ``` Run "my-app:app-shell" ``` ng run my-app:app-shell ``` ## üî• Exception or Error 


ERROR in Module build failed (from ./node_modules/sass-loader/lib/loader.js):

@import 'test';
       ^
      Can't find stylesheet to import.
  ‚ï∑
1 ‚îÇ @import 'test';
  ‚îÇ         ^^^^^^
  ‚ïµ
  stdin 1:9  root stylesheet
      in D:\Projects\Nodejs\my-app\src\app\app.component.scss (line 1, column 9)
## üåç Your Environment 



Angular CLI: 8.3.18
Node: 10.17.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.2.13

@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.803.18
@angular-devkit/core              8.3.18
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.3.18
@angular/cli                      8.3.18

@schematics/angular               8.3.18
@schematics/update                0.803.18
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.5.3

**Anything else relevant?** I tried to follow https://angular.io/guide/app-shell I first got the error in an angular 7 project, but I get the same error when testing it in a new angular 8 project. This error only occurs when running the "ng run my-app:app-shell" command

Fixes #16133

Issues.Title: docs(@angular/cli): Adds developer documentation and Intellij setup.
Issues.Body:
I wrote down my understanding of the best ways to build/run/test/debug this repository. I also included some configs for Intellij to work a little bit better "out of the box".

I tried to get VSCode to work as well, however the debugger there was having trouble loading source maps, so I'll need to come back to that later.

Changes include:
* Updated README with instructions for new developers.
* Updated .gitignore for Intellij and VSCode.
* Added Intellij config files.
* Added `nodemon` as a dev dependency, which is needed for watch executions but wasn't listed.
* Removed an extraneous `debugger;` statement which I kept hitting.
* Added support for negated .gitignore expressions in the build tool, as my changes to that file were causing build errors.

Issues.Title: Migrating to v9 => automatically migrate deprecated APIs via schematics
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a v8 project where the `import { SelectionModel } from '@angular/cdk/collections';` is being used
2. Use the `SelectionModel`'s deprecated `onChanged` API
3. Upgrade to the latest v9 RC release via `ng update @angular/material@next`
 
#### Expected Behavior

As quickly discussed with @jelbourn and @StephenFluin I'd expect the upgrade to happen automatically, meaning the `onChanged` should  be automatically migrated to the new `changed` API.

#### Actual Behavior

The code is not migrated.

#### Environment

- Angular: v8
- CDK/Material: v8
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macos
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Migrating to v9 => automatically migrate deprecated APIs via schematics" (#17683)

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/mdc-chips): use ripple target for state interactions
Issues.Body: Similar to what we did with button, checkbox. Use MDC's ripple target container for state interactions (focus, hover, active) rather than trying to do our own. This reduces our amount of overrides, aligns us better with their styles, fixes some bugs (e.g. the state color should match the text color, right now its always black), and helps us get it into using GM styles
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material-experimental/mdc-chips): use ripple target for state interactions" (#17681)

Issues.Title: build: enable bazel node modules symlinking
Issues.Body:
Enables bazel managed node modules symlinking (similar to what framework does)

* Easier way to make manual changes to debug issues
* Less disk size since we do not need to maintain two instances of `node_modules`
* Caching of node modules in CI. Bazel previously discarded the whole node
modules folder if the lock file changed.

**Note**: The postinstall patches script had to be updated to cover the following cases:

* It should throw if a new patch is added but does not apply
* It should _not_ throw if the same patch is applied on restored `node_modules` (i.e. from cache)
* CircleCI should not use cached node modules if the postinstall script changes. This previously wasn't necessary since Bazel always invalidated the whole node modules folder.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: enable bazel node modules symlinking" (#17675)

Issues.Title: build: expand decorators validation rule to cover class members
Issues.Body:
Expands the lint rule that we use to validate class decorators to also apply to class members. We need this in order to support linting things like `descendants` on `ContentChildren`.

These changes switch around the config data structure to make it more flexible, fix some cases where we were using `any` and add some extra properties to the config.

Issues.Body:
Basically the same idea of PR #9586, which _fixed_ #9582, but unfortunately didn't add a TSLint rule to keep these changes consistent.

Now, I'm adding `Codelyzer`'s `prefer-output-readonly` rule to the `tslint.json` :).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: make all event emitters readonly" (#17666)

Issues.Title: perf(youtube-player): triggering change detection for unused events
Issues.Body:
Currently the YouTube player component events all trigger change detection and are registered ahead of time, even if they aren't being used. These changes only set up the events if somebody is subscribed to them.

Also fixes a case where `first` was being used instead of `take(1)`. We want to avoid `first`, because it'll throw if the observable completes before emitting.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(youtube-player): triggering change detection for unused events" (#17665)

Issues.Title: fix(google-maps): avoid event listener leaks if inputs change
Issues.Body: Currently we initialize the map-related event listeners inside a subscription in the various map components, however the only time we remove them is on destroy. This can lead to leaks if the subcription fires multiple times. Note that at the moment we have a guard in place in the form of `take(1)`, but we could easily end up with event leaks if it were to be moved/removed if we decided to make it to react to changes post initialization.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(google-maps): avoid event listener leaks if inputs change" (#17664)

Issues.Title: google-maps: perf: defer event listener subscription
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Currently every google-maps component will add all of its possible event listeners just in case. It might boost performance not to do so until anything listens to this. I a not sure if it is possible with event emitters. 

#### Use Case

Possible performance benefits while using maps components.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "google-maps: perf: defer event listener subscription" (#17663)

Issues.Title: feat(badge): add test harness
Issues.Body: Sets up a test harness for the badge directive.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(badge): add test harness" (#17661)

Issues.Title: Keyboard navigation does not work in menus when using an item component
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-lxzdru

Steps to reproduce:
1. Define a custom component to use as the menu items
2. Click on the menu button OR tab to the button and hit enter
3. When the menu appears, the first menu item is not focused. And hitting the down arrow does not focus the next item.
 
#### Expected Behavior

After opening the menu, you can use down/up arrows to focus a menu item

#### Actual Behavior

Using the up/down arrows do not focus menu items

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.9
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System:  Windows

I determined that this functionality broke starting in Material version 8.1.0. Before that version, it worked correctly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Keyboard navigation does not work in menus when using an item component" (#17660)

Issues.Title: fix(bidi): ensure consistent interface between service and directive
Issues.Body:
Currently the `bidi` module has a `Directionality` service and a `Dir` directive. The directive re-provides itself as the service, however it doesn't have the same interface and behavior can cause inconsistencies depending on where it's injected. E.g. the directive has a `dir` property whereas the service doesn't. Also the directive will emit when it's value is re-assigned, but the service won't.

These changes bring the two closer together by moving the functionality into the service and having the directive extend it.

Somewhat related to https://github.com/angular/components/issues/17637, because it means that consumers can't notify the service when the value has changed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(bidi): ensure consistent interface between service and directive" (#17659)
